    A very good paper I came across this morning by the DeepMind researchers. For the past five years Transformers have been one of the most dominant approaches to Deep Learning problems, especially in the #NLP domain. However, despite many interesting papers on the topic, and lots of good open code, there has been a noticeable lack of *formal* definition of what transformed are, especially on the level of pseudocode. This paper aims to rectify that. It provides pseudocode for almost all major Transformer architectures, including training algorithms. One of the main benefits of having this pseudocode available is for the researchers who want to expand and modify some aspects of the transformer architecture, and go beyond any particular framework or even ML paradigm.     Context switches can be costly to recover from. In this post, I'll share a few tips from Elaine Meyer on reducing the cost of context switches, which can improve productivity and reduce frustration. When we context switch, our brains receive multiple stimuli at once. This leads to a kind of ‚Äúresponse selection bottleneck‚Äù that slows thought and decision-making. Upon returning to a task after a distraction, it can take up to 23 minutes to re-focus. How can you manage to get back in that flow state just a little quicker? For example, you can break up your mental model of your larger tasks into smaller ones. If you‚Äôre in the middle of something so complex you would forget if you had to step away for a few minutes or are interrupted, persist that state somewhere outside of your brain - write it down somewhere!. I highly recommend reading "The productivity tax you pay for context switching" by Elaine (https://lnkd.in/gVJSW8c6) which includes some concrete suggestions for reducing the cost of context switches: 1. Promote thoughtful, asynchronous communication Do your part to minimize the context switching others have to do. Change your workplace‚Äôs ‚Äúalways on‚Äù culture by encouraging asynchronous communication. Make it clear team members aren‚Äôt expected to give an immediate, real-time response to emails or team chats. 2. Capture tasks somewhere that‚Äôs not your head Just thinking about another task splits our attention and makes it harder to focus on what‚Äôs in front of us in the moment. Studies show that simply making a plan to complete a task later helps to reduce repetitive thoughts about the task. 3. Have a go-to framework for prioritizing tasks Focusing on one thing at a time starts with deciding what that thing will be. However, when your priorities aren‚Äôt clear, deciding what to do can become its own distraction. Distinguish between high-value, non-urgent tasks and low-value, urgent ones with the Eisenhower decision matrix. Get realistic about what you actually have time for. 4. Batch your tasks and block your time Once you know what you‚Äôll focus on, you‚Äôll need a daily structure for staying focused on it. Task batching, time blocking, time-boxing and pomodoros are all useful tools at your disposal. What are they? - Task batching: Grouping and performing similar tasks together - Time blocking: Dividing your day into blocks, such as ‚Äúmeetings,‚Äù ‚Äúemail,‚Äù and ‚Äúdeep work‚Äù. - Time boxing: Setting a limit on how much time you spend on a task 5. Proactively eliminate as many distractions as possible Even if you think you‚Äôre going to read just one email, it‚Äôs hard not to get sucked deeper into your inbox once you‚Äôve opened it. Try to focus on one task, screen, app, and window at a time, and eliminate what causes you to switch contexts in the first place ‚Äî the buzzes and screen notifications and excess tabs in your web browser. #softwareengineering #productivity[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6961038258197716992?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6961038258197716992%29)

That English makes up less than 1/3 of its unprecedented training set, and is broadly comprised of diverse other sources such as Chinese, Niger-Congo and coding examples.     Information Gain (IG) is defined as a measure of how much information a feature provides about a class. IG helps to determine the order of attributes in the nodes of a decision tree. The main node is referred to as the parent node, whereas sub-nodes are known as child nodes. IG is the amount of information gained about a random variable from observing another random variable. Entropy is the average rate at which information is a measure of the uncertainty associated with a random variable. In Data Science and Machine Learning, IG is calculated for a split by subtracting the weighted entropies of each branch from the original entropy. When training a Decision Tree using these metrics, the best split is chosen by maximizing IG. The variable that has the largest IG is selected to split the dataset. Generally, a larger gain indicates a smaller entropy or less surprise. Entropy, as it relates to Machine Learning, is a measure of the randomness in the information being processed. The higher the entropy, the harder it is to draw conclusions from that information. The lower the entropy in Machine Learning, the more accurate the prediction we can make. Due to the entropy measurement, we can decide which variables are the most efficient to split on, making a decision tree more effective and accurate.     ùêÄùêß ùêàùêßùê≠ùê´ùê®ùêùùêÆùêúùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêß ùê≠ùê® ùêãùê¢ùêüùêûùê•ùê®ùêßùê† ùêíùêÆùê©ùêûùê´ùêØùê¢ùê¨ùêûùêù ùêãùêûùêöùê´ùêßùê¢ùêßùê† by Shagun Sodhani et al from #fair üéØ ùêìùê°ùêû ùêãùê¢ùêüùêûùê•ùê®ùêßùê† ùêãùêûùêöùê´ùêßùê¢ùêßùê† ùê©ùêöùê´ùêöùêùùê¢ùê†ùê¶ is the branch of AI that focuses on developing lifelong learning systems - systems that keep accumulating new knowledge throughout their lifetime without forgetting the prior knowledge and use this accumulated knowledge to improve their performance on the different tasks. üéØ We highlight that the lifelong learning paradigm is not unique to the multi-task setup and applies to the single-task setup as well. Lifelong learning is a general setup since it makes fewer assumptions about the task (or tasks). üéØ Consider a standard single-task supervised learning setup where the learner can access the entire dataset before starting the training. In this case, the learner can perform multiple epochs over the dataset, shuffling the data in each epoch to keep the data distribution, i.i.d (independent and identically distributed). üéØ However, there are many implicit assumptions in this setup - since we have access to the dataset beforehand, we know how many unique classes exist in the dataset. We also have access to the class distribution and can weigh the classes differently. We can also over/under-sample the data. üéØ While these assumptions make the setup amenable for training, they also take the setup away from the more general open-ended learning setup. üéØ If we were not to assume access to the dataset (or even the number of unique classes), the AI system would have to address challenges like modifying the network architecture as it sees new classes, not forgetting the old data points as it trains on new data points and potentially increasing the capacity of the system as new data keeps coming in. üéØ All these challenges are studied under the paradigm of lifelong learning. ùêÉùê®ùê∞ùêßùê•ùê®ùêöùêù ùêãùê¢ùêßùê§: https://lnkd.in/d4fhVYSZ üçì üçí ùï±ùñîùñëùñëùñîùñú Michael(Mike) Erlihson, PhD for awesome DS/ML/math resources üçì üçí #lifelonglearning #machinelearning #continuallearning[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6953037478861639680?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6953037478861639680%29)

    Accelerate your NN training and converge faster: BatchNorm (BN) and LayerNorm (LN) Sergey Ioffe and Christian Szegedy‚Äôs 2015 paper, "Batch Normalization: Accelerating Deep Network Training by Reducing Internal Covariate Shift" introduced the idea of BN Internal Covariate Shift is a fancy name for the **change in the distribution of network activations** due to the change in network parameters during training across layers. (See the figure, how activations create the shift and how BN fixes it) üëâ What does it mean in practice? Some classical algorithms and NNs expect normalized data i.e a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1. The authors showed not only ensure data is normalized before entering training but ensure it stays normalized while it‚Äôs training across layers for each mini-batch. Hence preventing the distribution changes. üëâ The above paper showed that fixing Internal Covariate shift with BN can: - Substantially decrease training time - Remove / Combine with drop-out - Decrease the quantum of regularization - Allow for increased learning rate Paper: https://lnkd.in/e2sj_EvK Next up we will examine Layer Norm Image source: https://lnkd.in/eEp9tBMA[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6950300588039401472?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6950300588039401472%29)

    If you think large companies with a massive userbase (Amazon, Google) have an easy time detecting tiny changes in A/B tests, you‚Äôre wrong! The number of users needed to detect a change grows quadratically in the sensitivity, so very large companies cannot detect changes that would lose them $10M/year. Let‚Äôs take a realistic example. You‚Äôre an e-commerce site selling widgets and 5% of users who visit during the experiment period end up purchasing. Those purchasing spend about $25. The average user therefore spends $1.25 (95% spend $0). Assume the standard deviation is $3. If you are running an A/B test and want to detect a 5% change to revenue, you plug this into the power formula: n=16 sigma^2/delta^2 as 16*3^2/(1.25*0.05)^2=36,864 users. Reasonable for a small company. Now you‚Äôre Amazon retail, or Google search with more than $100B in annual revenue. Your CFO says that s/he thinks $10M is material enough to know if you‚Äôre gaining or losing that much in your experiments (which may be optimizing for something else altogether, so this is a guardrail metric). Your delta is now 10M/100B = 0.01%. Because it‚Äôs squared in the denominator, you‚Äôre in trouble. 16*3^2/(1.25*0.0001)^2 > 9.2B users in each variant, a problem when the earth‚Äôs population is under 8B. The largest companies cannot power experiments with enough users to detect a $10M loss. QED. To learn more, see my book https://lnkd.in/eWuqBVw and 10-hour interactive Zoom class on ScholarSite: https://https://bit.ly/ABClassRKLI . For other intuition busters in #ABTesting, see our upcoming KDD 2022 paper: https://lnkd.in/gqbtzZDg .     Comment: Good overview with extensive references Title: Natural and Artificial Intelligence: A brief introduction to the interplay between AI and neuroscience research See‚Ä¶ https://lnkd.in/ecASyj9P Abstract: Neuroscience and artificial intelligence (AI) share a long history of collaboration. Advances in neuroscience, alongside huge leaps in computer processing power over the last few decades, have given rise to a new generation of in silico neural networks inspired by the architecture of the brain. These AI systems are now capable of many of the advanced perceptual and cognitive abilities of biological systems, including object recognition and decision making. Moreover, AI is now increasingly being employed as a tool for neuroscience research and is transforming our understanding of brain functions. In particular, deep learning has been used to model how convolutional layers and recurrent connections in the brain‚Äôs cerebral cortex control important functions, including visual processing, memory, and motor control. Excitingly, the use of neuroscience-inspired AI also holds great promise for understanding how changes in brain networks result in psychopathologies, and could even be utilized in treatment regimes. Here we discuss recent advancements in four areas in which the relationship between neuroscience and AI has led to major advancements in the field; (1) AI models of working memory, (2) AI visual processing, (3) AI analysis of big neuroscience datasets, and (4) computational psychiatry.[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6947862891882545152?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6947862891882545152%29)

    Many of the our common neural network architectures (CNNs, LSTMs, transformers etc.) can be described as special cases under a more generic framework known as geometric deep learning. The main idea is that each of these neural networks types impose some invariance or equivariance under some certain set of transformations of the data. For example the convolutional layers are equivariant to translations, i.e. translating (shifting) the input also translates the output by the same amount. Transformers on the other hand are permutation equivariant, so permuting the input sequence will also permute the output sequence in the same way. Thus the architectures you choose defines a prior or "inductive bias" which constrains what we can or needs to be learned.     The mystery of the ever-growing number of activation functions: Is there a secret to picking the right one? ReLU was the prominent one for a long time in spite of its shortcomings, 10s if not 100s of alternatives were proposed. Nothing could take over. #Google üß† released their ‚ÄúSearching for activation functions‚Äù paper in 2017 and claimed they exhaustively searched and figured out a simple variant or sigmoid called Swish it is the King now. Apparently, numbers claimed Swish smoked ReLU and cousins in vision tasks. But #OpenAI GPT2 paper showed they used an activation similar to Swish but a lot faster called GELU. Here is a common pattern, then on: Many NLP papers used GELU and Vision tasks used Swish (or some later variants). In the same spirit recently ReLU6 gained the spotlight. So what‚Äôs the secret? Anecdotal evidence from practitioners suggests that ReLU still is the ‚Äúacceptable‚Äù choice for discriminatory tasks and it's dying neurons problem serendipitously moonlights as a dropout. You need to worry about sophisticated activation functions only when you are dealing with Pretraining or dealing with generative tasks. Just reporting what I have gathered speaking to folks, not a prescription. If something else works for you go with it by all means.     This seemingly innocuous little thing can break your ML projects. Grab a coffee, Look at figure A and allow me to un-complicate one sliver of this huge complication. üëâModel Calibration, Confidence, and Reliability: Don‚Äôt let the idea of passing raw logits into a softmax (or a sigmoid) function (giving a multinomial distribution) trick you into thinking we get probability scores. They are not and they certainly don‚Äôt reflect the confidence as-is. If done right the probability gives you some kind of confidence in the prediction and improves reliability. The problem of predicting ‚Äúprobability estimates‚Äù representative of the true correctness likelihood -- is important for discriminative models in many applications. This problem plagues most models not just NNs but some more than others. Modern NNs are poorly calibrated but even classic models from sci-kit learn has this problem and they speak about it in detail (second link in the reference section), in fact, they have a dedicated class ‚Äú CalibratedClassifierCV‚Äù if this is important to you. Surprisingly most popular libraries have not integrated this as a 1st class feature into their library and left this to the MLEs to handle. üëâMathematically speaking: Model calibration is the process by which model parameters are adjusted to ‚Äôbest‚Äô describe/fit known observations. For a given model M, Y = M(X;Œ∏), where Œ∏ represents the model parameters. üëâMy experience In 2019 a project needed heavy reliance on the model confidence, so we attempted calibrating the scores. I can‚Äôt go into details, but it is NOT hard for you to imagine a real-world use case that cannot tolerate even a 5% gap between the uncalibrated model confidence and actual confidence. It's a simple 2-step process. * Diagnose - Reliability diagrams - Flavour 1 - Calibration curves (also known as reliability diagrams) - Flavour 2 * Calibrate (Surprisingly simple post-processing calibration methods) - Temperature scaling, - Histogram binning, - Isotonic regression - Beta Calibration A: Shows the reality of building models, taking them to prod, monitoring it, and pulling the plug if needed. Our focus is on RED (Model calibration) B: Shows the gap between confidence and accuracy of the popular Resnet-152 on ImageNet, before and after various calibrations. As you can see temperature scaling closes the gap best in this example. C: Calibration Plots of Classic models üëâPython Implementation: https://lnkd.in/eQDqvbQp üëâReferences: - Heavy lifting is done - https://lnkd.in/eXZbrNnW - Sklearn supports calibration, they claim predict_proba methods handle it. - Sci-kit learn probability calibration - https://lnkd.in/exEyery5[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6946017446516424704?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6946017446516424704%29)

    How to deal with missing data in 2022? 1. 'text book' solutions. It's usually 'deleting data' or 'imputing data'. Which one should you choose? There is no standard answer, but it's important to analyze the distribution of data to answer some questions: Before you delete rows/columns with missing data: It's key to understand why the data is missing. ‚Ä¢ Are those data missing randomly? Are there any pattern? Maybe the missing roles or columns are correlated to another factor, and blindly removing them might bias your data. Or maybe the missing values belong to a different category. ‚Ä¢ Do you have enough data to train? If not, maybe you can't afford to delete rows with missing data. Before you impute data: ‚Ä¢ do you know the distribution the data? If you don't, maybe you should use simple method like median/mean, or averaging values of the k nearest neighbors, instead of using a complex function. Because the imputation method might introduce unknown variance to the data and it might deviate from the truth. 2. Use gradient boosting trees. XGBoost and other gradient boosting trees generally handles missing data well. It uses a 'sparsity-aware split finding' algorithm to learn how to best split the missing value in the tree. This is one of the reason data scientists use XGBoost to train their model when they have missing data or the data is sparse. I have used XGBoost for a project for the exact reason, and it worked better than other models. 3. Encode missing value as a new feature. You can add a binary column where you say this was a missing value and this wasn't, and you can you feed the data to an XGBoost model. XGBoost already knows how to deal with missing data, but if you have an indicator, it can actually learn better. This is called "missing value as a feature". It's recommended by Jesper Dramsch, PhD, scientist of machine learning. *I interviewed Jesper on 'the data scientist show' and we talked more about how to deal with missing data, Kaggle expert tips.     We have remotely deployed Differentiable Predictive Control (DPC) onto a laboratory device equipped with a Raspberry Pi microcontroller that we have never seen in real. Sim2Real setup: Step 1, We obtained time series dataset of the device input-output dynamics from our colleagues in Europe. Step 2, We perfomed nonlinear system identificaiton with neural state space models. Step 3, We formulate parametric constrained optimal control problem. Step 4, We solve the problem offline with DPC policy optimization obtaining neural control policies. Step 5, We ship the trained policies back to our colleagues in Europe who deploy them on a real device. This work represents an important milestone that serves as a proof of concept that DPC is suitable to be used in control as a service setting. In the laboratory settings, we compared the control performance, computational requirements, and memory footprint of DPC with explicit model predictive control (MPC). We found out that DPC was able to learn policies competitive to MPC while significantly reducing computational and memory demands compared to explicit MPC. title: Differentiable predictive control: Deep learning alternative to explicit model predictive control for unknown nonlinear systems full paper: https://lnkd.in/gcmPfHUz implemented using Neuromancer toolbox: https://lnkd.in/gqbVs2uY Huge thanks to all co-authors: Karol Ki≈° Martin Klauco Aaron Tuor Draguna Vrabie #deeplearning #sim2real #controlsystems[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6945013362703437825?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6945013362703437825%29)

    Pro-Tips to amass *respectable* technical readership on Linkedin. If building readership is a multivariate equation then all the below tips are variables of different weights (or say multipliers). Some may give you 2x and some may give 10x. üëâ 1: Have a public proof of wide impact: Now, what does it look like in practice? Let's call it X, X = The delta, Œî(Your contribution , Status Quo) * the number of people whom it might help. If X is high, people would like to follow you for your unique, needle-moving work. This is what Gramformer, Styleformer & Parrot Paraphraser did to me. Btw Parrot is the number #1 paraphrase gen library in HF as of today with 200K+ downloads, https://lnkd.in/eH8F6ruZ üëâ 2: Increase your luck surface area: Make your name synonymous with something. Winning a single ML competition can get your name out farther than 10 blog posts can ever could. Why ? it is a rare event. That's what WhatTheFood (WTF) did to me. The WTF app by itself created a lot of excitement, winning the 1st prize of 1000 $ was a cherry on top. üëâ3: Use Nifty Visuals to convey complex ideas: Why? Visuals have at least 2 orders of magnitude lesser cognitive load compared to text. I liberally use memes & hand-drawn visuals to convey ideas. This is what my original "Transformers are a unicorn" and the "Jealous Cross entropy loss looks at Contrastive loss" memes did to me. My nifty visuals on F0.5, SVM kernel trick, Cross-attention & Gradient Checkpointing did to me. They garnered huge engagement and put me on the map. üëâ 4: Show depth in your content. Don't get me wrong! Content about useful libraries is a great way to start but there is a subtle difference between a pure content broking and a content creation. I do content broking too, but that's a small portion of what I share. if you draw a spider chart of my content types, Organic, deep, and niche content will pull through 80-85% of it. My primer on topic models, the multi-part series on vector search engines, and mental models on multimodal modeling are great examples that garnered maximum engagement. üëâ 5: Instead of asking people to follow you, let your content give them a compelling reason to follow you: I learned this from Bill Maher (Standup comic and Political satirist, now on HBO). When all the late-night TV hosts in the US were forced to make shorts to say "Like & Subscribe" to their digital content on YouTube, Maher refused. All great creators I know of unconsciously does this. Ask yourself "have I given enough reasons for people to follow me". I mean "+ Follow" button is right there, if they like it they will follow you, relax :-) üëâ 6: Having the blessings of super-spreaders & influencers of your niche in your network helps if they engage. designed for rotating LiDAR point sequences. üëâ Helix4D operates on acquisition slices that correspond to a fraction of a full rotation of the sensor, significantly reducing the total latency. üëâ     CorEx Topic, A new name in topic modeling based on CorEx & seems closer to BERTTopic. New to Topic Models? Here, an Intentionally short primer. Repo in comments üëá üëâ Case A: Discover topics in a corpus with long-form docs of size: small to medium & you are open to dealing with cleanup (stop words), muck with hyper-parameters & involve HITL to assign readable topics. - Use cases: Analyse employee emails (long-form) to understand the top N topics that lead to mass resignations. - 2 Options: Matrix factorisation (MF)-based & Probabilistic sampling-based. - Mode: Unsupervised A variant of MF: Decompose a term-doc frequency matrix A into W & H (in W, all rows (i) are docs & cols (j) are words, in H, all rows are words & cols are topics). Imagine Wij. Hjk. K is the number of topics & it is manually chosen. Idea is to reduce i.e ||A-W.H||. If SVD is used for MF then it‚Äôs LSA. The probabilistic variation of it is pLSA. Another variation of pLSA is NMF. But if you do this probabilistically using sampling tech like Gibbs sampling then it‚Äôs LDA. - Pros: The topics are open for good human interpretations. - Cons: By default, the word is the tactical unit, and word order & context are ignored (Though you could play with the ngram range while generating a term-doc matrix, it‚Äôs still a BoW). You are also at the mercy of the implementation, I have ‚Äúheard‚Äù Mallet is ‚Äúdecent‚Äù. Finally, Can‚Äôt handle a huge corpus. üëâ Case B: Discover topics in a corpus of long or short texts & you don‚Äôt want to deal with corpus cleanup, a lot of hyper-parameters, leveraging SoTA LMs with some convenient features. - Use cases: Prev use-case + Analyse Trump tweets to understand the topics during the Capitol invasion - 2 Options: Top2vec & BERTopic - Mode: Top2vec (Unsupervised) & BERTopic (can do supervised, semi/guided & DTM). Both follow the same 5 steps, vectorize docs using algorithms (in the likes of Doc2Vec all the way up to Transformers), lower dimensions of docs using UMAP, make clusters using HDBSCAN, calculate centroids (which is the topic) & get Top N similar or closer docs to the centroids. But BERTopic varies in the last 2 steps (which is its weakness) & in the list of vectorization algorithms it supports. Ref the papers for more. - Pros: Both have some nice bells & whistles like search & Viz. The results show both work better with short texts with better coherence & diversity. SoTA vectorization algorithms take care of topic & doc semantics. - Cons: High-quality doc vectors come at a price & can be very slow. The main drawback of BERTTopic is that even though docs are vectorized using semantic vectors the topics are still vectorized using a variant of a BoW called c-TF-IDF. This is still a challenge. üëâ Case C: Your docs are represented by many *correlated* topics. Go for variational inference-based CTM - Correlated topic models. Fx BERTopic assumes "A doc pertains to one topic more than others" but it is far from reality in certain domains.[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6943803823261925376?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6943803823261925376%29)

    ML interpretability in the business process is very important. In my experience, business people want to know how the model works rather than the metric evaluation itself. One of the best packages for ML Interpretability is Yellowbrick. Yellowbrick is an open-source Python package that extends the scikit-learn API with visual analysis and diagnostic tools. For Data scientists, Yellowbrick is used to evaluate the model performance and visualize the model behavior. Yellowbrick is a multi-purpose package you could use in everyday modeling work. Even though most of the interpretation API from the Yellowbrick is at the basic level, it is still useful for our first modeling steps.     How do you research something that doesn‚Äôt exist yet? This is a question that researchers at Cruise who are trying to design the consumer-facing experience come up against regularly. Before joining Cruise I worked at Uber, where customers were abundant. It was easy to send a screener survey to 500 customers with a goal of scheduling 10‚Äì15 interviews. If we needed to send out a survey, sample sizes were no problem. Walking down the street you were sure to see someone getting in or out of an Uber. Inspiration and information was everywhere. Research is a different story at a startup that has not launched a product yet ‚Äì especially when the product is unlike anything that existed before. In the years before Cruise received permits to give public rides we did not have any customers to learn from. Legally and technically we could not take people on rides in our cars to observe their first experience with a self-driving car. To help our product and design teams build a ridehail product that the world will love, we needed to explore new methods for conducting research.     ESVP: A lightning-fast and $$ conscious explainer for transformers is now available in Streamlit cloud as an interim fix. Demo: https://lnkd.in/eCZPpqdm ------- For those who are new to ESVP. Below B-school style, the graph shows where ESVP stands. ESVP is a lightweight, ultra-fast, simple yet novel ‚Äúmodel interpretation by feature attribution‚Äù technique for HF transformer models that addresses all the below concerns in commodity hardware. Motivation: The principal goal of a model explanation is to offer a transparent view of the ‚Äúwhat & why‚Äù of a machine‚Äôs prediction to humans. Because of this goal historically there was a heavy emphasis on accurate explanations. For instance, üëâFor classic models, methods like SHAPELY are really accurate but are additive in nature and by design, it is exhaustive hence it was relatively slower even for classic linear and tree-based models (hence we resorted to faster LIME, though it works locally). üëâFor DNNs, back-prop-based methods like Integrated Gradients were really accurate but calculates expensive gradients (both in terms of memory and compute) to derive explanations. (Think about this there is a reason why during inference we deliberately use no-grad to avoid calculating gradients.) üëâSlow and expensive = It's going to cost you an extra $. üëâToday massive transformer models can operate in millisecond inference budget, So it is impractical to have an explanation method or pipeline that has a latency and/or compute needs > inference budget as they aid humans-in-the-loop. Neither extending SHAPELY for transformer models nor latching on to expensive back-prop-based methods makes sense. üëâOn the surface it might sound like there are many techniques (Shapley to Integrated Gradients) and libraries (Captum to AllenAI interpret) but if you go beyond scratching the surface almost all incumbent techniques trade-off speed & resource appetite for the accuracy or vice versa. For aficionados, the name takes after RSVP, which translates to ‚ÄúRespond, please‚Äù, ESVP translates to ‚ÄúExplain, please‚Äù. üòÄ #explainableai[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6943174500796530689?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6943174500796530689%29)

    Check out our #CVPR2022 paper where we use a fusion transformer trained with combinatorial loss in order to gain better accuracy on Youcook2/MSR-VTT! paper: https://lnkd.in/ev2frqi2 github link: https://lnkd.in/eEwCSGAW We propose a multi-modal, modality agnostic fusion transformer that learns to exchange information between multiple modalities, such as video, audio, and text, and integrate them into a joined multi-modal representation to obtain an embedding that aggregates multi-modal temporal information. We train the system with a combinatorial loss on everything at once, single modalities as well as pairs of modalities, explicitly leaving out any add-ons such as position or modality encoding. At test time, the resulting model can process and fuse any number of input modalities and process inputs of different lengths. Training on HowTo100M dataset, we show state-of-the-art results in zero-shot video retrieval and zero-shot video action localization.     Exciting stuff by Google and many others: the Beyond the Imitation Game benchmark (BIG-bench). It currently consists of 204 tasks, contributed by 442 authors across 132 institutions. Task topics are diverse, drawing problems from linguistics, childhood development, math, common-sense reasoning, biology, physics, social bias, software development, and beyond. BIG-bench focuses on tasks that are believed to be beyond the capabilities of current language models. The authors evaluate the behavior of OpenAI‚Äôs GPT models, Google-internal dense transformer architectures, and Switch-style sparse transformers on BIG-bench, across model sizes spanning millions to hundreds of billions of parameters. In addition, a team of human expert raters performed all tasks in order to provide a strong baseline. Now for the interesting stuff - findings include: - model performance and calibration both improve with scale, but are poor in absolute terms (and when compared with rater performance); - performance is remarkably similar across model classes, though with benefits from sparsity; - tasks that improve gradually and predictably commonly involve a large knowledge or memorization component, whereas tasks that exhibit ‚Äúbreakthrough‚Äù behavior at a critical scale often involve multiple steps or components, or brittle metrics; - social bias typically increases with scale in settings with ambiguous context, but this can be improved with prompting.[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6940856216424235008?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6940856216424235008%29)

    Title: You thought quantum mechanics was weird: check out entangled time See‚Ä¶ https://lnkd.in/eXQG-FAN ‚ÄúIn the summer of 1935, the physicists Albert Einstein and Erwin Schr√∂dinger engaged in a rich, multifaceted and sometimes fretful correspondence about the implications of the new theory of quantum mechanics. The focus of their worry was what Schr√∂dinger later dubbed entanglement: the inability to describe two quantum systems or particles independently, after they have interacted. Until his death, Einstein remained convinced that entanglement showed how quantum mechanics was incomplete. Schr√∂dinger thought that entanglement was the defining feature of the new physics, but this didn‚Äôt mean that he accepted it lightly. ‚ÄòI know of course how the hocus pocus works mathematically,‚Äô he wrote to Einstein on 13 July 1935. ‚ÄòBut I do not like such a theory.‚Äô Schr√∂dinger‚Äôs famous cat, suspended between life and death, first appeared in these letters, a byproduct of the struggle to articulate what bothered the pair. The problem is that entanglement violates how the world ought to work. Information can‚Äôt travel faster than the speed of light, for one. But in a 1935 paper, Einstein and his co-authors showed how entanglement leads to what‚Äôs now called quantum nonlocality, the eerie link that appears to exist between entangled particles. If two quantum systems meet and then separate, even across a distance of thousands of lightyears, it becomes impossible to measure the features of one system (such as its position, momentum and polarity) without instantly steering the other into a corresponding state. Up to today, most experiments have tested entanglement over spatial gaps. The assumption is that the ‚Äònonlocal‚Äô part of quantum nonlocality refers to the entanglement of properties across space. But what if entanglement also occurs across time? Is there such a thing as temporal nonlocality.‚Äù PS: I‚Äôve been banging on a while about this notion PS: I‚Äôve been banging on a while about this notion!     This cheat sheet is a condensed version of machine learning manual, which contains many classical equations and diagrams on machine learning, and aims to help you quickly recall knowledge and ideas in machine learning. This cheat sheet has two significant advantages: 1. Clearer symbols. Mathematical formulas use quite a lot of confusing symbols. For example, X can be a set, a random variable, or a matrix. This is very confusing and makes it very difficult for readers to understand the meaning of math formulas. This cheat sheet tries to standardize the usage of symbols, and all symbols are clearly pre-defined 2. Less thinking jumps. In many machine learning books, authors omit some intermediary steps of a mathematical proof process, which may save some space but causes difficulty for readers to understand this formula and readers get lost in the middle way of the derivation process. This cheat sheet tries to keep important intermediary steps as where as possible.     State-of-the-art probabilistic forecasting is now available in Nixtla üéâüéâüéâ Recently, at Nixtla, we released the N-HiTS model, significantly improving accuracy and ‚ö° computational time (over 50 times) over Transformer-based methods. Today we are excited to make MQN-HiTS available. It combines the N-HiTS with the multi quantile loss enabling it to produce accurate and efficient probabilistic forecasts in long-horizon settings üî•üî•üî• You can find a Colab example here: https://lnkd.in/gn4AJXr6 Making predictions for the future involves varying degrees of imperfect or unknown information that translates into uncertainty. For this reason, probabilistic forecasting has emerged as a possible answer to quantify the uncertainty of the future of the target variable, conditioning on the available information of its predictors. We tested the MQN-HiTS model using the M4-Hourly dataset, and we found that even without tuning, it produces faster and more accurate predictions than AutoARIMA + the advantages of probabilistic forecasting.     Let's start with a stack of documents, and you have no idea about the content of these documents. A common data science approach is to use topic modeling to identify the main topics of all these documents. These topics provide an easy shorthand for starting to understand the content of these documents. The animated image shows the process for topic clustering. It really is that easy! Start with taking your documents and getting them organized into one table. The BERTopic package uses state-of-the-art transformer models to build document embeddings and cluster them into topics. Additionally, BERTopic also offers several easy ways to visualize the final results. My favorite is to view the topics changing over time. If you want more details, check out the BERTopic site and a simple demo I have put together. In this demo, I find topics across 20 years of news headlines. The dataset and code for the app are all open source and available from the demo app. Jump in, this is a very powerful package that is not difficult to use.     #FPGAs deliver both software and hardware solutions with low #power, high #performance, #reconfigurability and more, serving as the promising computing substrate for #robotic applications. Zishen, Ashwin, Bo, Shaoshan, yu, Vijay, Hao and Arijit write about this in their article "Robotic Computing on FPGAs: Current Progress, Research Challenges, and Opportunities". In particular, the authors highlight the following research challenges and future directions: (1) #Reconfiguring robotic #computing at run time, (2) #Modularizing robotic computing #kernels design, (3) Mapping robotic computing on heterogeneous platforms, (4) Connecting FPGA to #ROS ecosystem, (5) #Benchmarking robotic computing kernels, (6) Automating robotic computing #design flow, (7) Building customized robotic computing with the open-source framework and (8) Integrating robotic computing #hardware in a #simulation loop. Our work at the #ROS2 Hardware Acceleration Working Group is paving the way towards tackling these challenges.     ‚úî‚ö° üåà üèÜü•á ùêÑùêüùêüùê¢ùêúùê¢ùêûùêßùê≠ùêÖùê®ùê´ùê¶ùêûùê´: ùêïùê¢ùê¨ùê¢ùê®ùêß ùêìùê´ùêöùêßùê¨ùêüùê®ùê´ùê¶ùêûùê´ùê¨ ùêöùê≠ ùêåùê®ùêõùê¢ùê•ùêûùêçùêûùê≠ ùêíùê©ùêûùêûùêù ‚úî‚ö° üåà üèÜü•á üéØ New Vision Transformer for Mobile Devices!! üéØ Vision Transformers (ViT) have shown rapid progress in computer vision tasks, achieving promising results on various benchmarks. üéØ However, due to the massive number of parameters and model design, e.g., attention mechanism, ViT-based models are generally times slower than lightweight convolutional networks. üéØ Therefore, the deployment of ViT for real-time applications is particularly challenging, especially on resource-constrained hardware such as mobile devices. üéØ Recent efforts try to reduce the computation complexity of ViT through network architecture search or hybrid design with MobileNet block, yet the inference speed is still unsatisfactory. üéØ This leads to an important question: can transformers run as fast as MobileNet while obtaining high performance? üéØ To answer this, we first revisit the network architecture and operators used in ViT-based models and identify inefficient designs. üéØ Then we introduce a dimension-consistent pure transformer (without MobileNet blocks) as design paradigm. üéØ Finally, we perform latency-driven slimming to get a series of final models dubbed EfficientFormer. üéØ Extensive experiments show the superiority of EfficientFormer in performance and speed on mobile devices. üéØ Our work proves that properly designed transformers can reach extremely low latency on mobile devices while maintaining high performance. ùêèùê´ùê®ùê£ùêûùêúùê≠: https://lnkd.in/dEmTm6zb ùêèùêöùê©ùêûùê´: https://lnkd.in/dQ629Urj ENJOY, LEARN & KEEP IMPROVING! üçì üçí ùï±ùñîùñëùñëùñîùñú Michael(Mike) Erlihson, PhD for awesome DS/ML/math resources üçì üçí #visiontransformers #mobile #transformers #vit[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6938747734770225152?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6938747734770225152%29)

Twint is a high level Python crawling tool that allows to scrape all the information available in Twitter public website without using the official API (limited in terms of the number of tweets that you can collect). ‚ÄúNo authentification. No API. No limits‚Äù. Twint retrieves all the tweets that belong to a certain author or specific search term/trend/hashtag (yes, all of them!!!) in a customizable time period. It also collects tweet metadata such as author (with followers and following), performance (likes, retweets, favorites), etc. üò± It is an amazing tool to incorporate in many social media application pipelines: monitoring, impact analysis, trends detection, etc. 100% recommended.     Introducing the OptFormer, the world's first text-based hyperparameter/blackbox optimizer based on Transformers!! Paper: https://lnkd.in/gF4WTuyk At Google, we possess one of the world's largest hyperparameter optimization databases, over some of Google's most important products and research efforts over the last 5 years. One crucial question is: How can we leverage such data to produce better optimizers? As it turns out, we can simply train a Transformer over such data. But the shocking part is: ùêñùêû ùêúùêöùêß ùêùùê® ùê¨ùê® ùê®ùêØùêûùê´ ùê´ùêöùê∞ ùê≠ùêûùê±ùê≠ùêÆùêöùê• ùê´ùêûùê©ùê´ùêûùê¨ùêûùêßùê≠ùêöùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêßùê¨ ùêüùê®ùê´ ùêÑùêïùêÑùêëùêòùêìùêáùêàùêçùêÜ, ùê¢ùêßùêúùê•ùêÆùêùùê¢ùêßùê† ùêßùêÆùê¶ùêõùêûùê´ùê¨. This allows the Transformer to read crucial metadata info like parameter names (e.g. "learning rate"), metric names (e.g. "accuracy"), and descriptions (e.g. "cifar10") to provide a much stronger prior over the objective to be optimized. Even more shocking were the results, which suggest that the Transformer is far more algorithmically and numerically capable than we realize: 1. The Transformer can precisely imitate multiple algorithms simultaneously - if we prompt the algorithm name (e.g. "Hill Climbing"), the Transformer will produce its behavior exactly. 2. It can also predict objective output values MUCH more accurately than Gaussian Processes, especially because the Transformer can read textual metadata cues. 3. By combining 1+2 using model-based techniques, we're able to produce tuning algorithms that outperform even our industry standard Google Vizier optimizer. We hope that this is the first step to a universal model for hyperparameter optimization and general intelligence for AutoML systems. This was a huge collaborative effort between Deepmind and Google Brain, with numerous amazing coauthors: Yutian Chen, Chansoo Lee, Zi Wang, Qiuyi Zhang, David Dohan, Kazuya Kawakami, Greg Kochanski, Arnaud Doucet, Marc'aurelio Ranzato, Sagi Perel, and Nando de Freitas.     How do we quickly merge data without Mircosoft Excel? . Here are 5 useful pandas functions for production data analysis. üîπ Concat: this function supports the vertical and horizontal combination of two tables. Concat can quickly combine the data from different shards. üîπ Append: this function supports the adding of data to an existing table. Append can be used in web crawlers. The new data can be appended to the table when it is crawled. üîπ Merge: this function supports horizontal combination on keys. It works similarly to database joins. Merge can be used to combine data from different domains with the same keys. üîπ Join: this function works similarly to database outer joins. üîπ Combine: this function can apply calculations while combining two tables. The example below chooses the smaller value for the cell. Combine is useful for a data cleansing process.     Flight simmers! This is the 5th and last episode on the application of #Matlab #Reinforcement #Learning Toolbox to flight control. This video wraps up the work conducted by me and my student Paolo Maria D'Onza on how classical flight control techniques compare to those based on AI. Typical autopilot systems for fixed-wing airplanes are made up of nested PID controllers, whose design often needs a careful gain tuning, and may become vulnerable to control instability in disturbed flight situations. Recent advances in Reinforcement Learning (RL) research, on the other hand, provide the possibility to implement *agents* (controllers) that are able to learn from interactions with their surrounding space and subsequent state transitions. When an agent is trained with *Deep Reinforcement learning (DRL)* techniques, there is the possibility to spread its control experience over many unusual possible states and correction actions. This becomes an important feature of the learning process in order to obtain good control skills within feasible learning times. This work investigates the use of DRL to manage and control a fixed wing high-performance aircraft. We have chosen a Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) agent, having studied the successful applications of this particular approach in other domains. In our particular application to flight control, our attention has been focused on the design of suitable *reward functions*, which encode the behavior we wanted the agent to learn. Starting from easy tasks, such as the straight and leveled flight control, it was possible to successfully train an agent to control more complex tasks, such as following a sequence of randomly generated waypoints. This unlocked the possibility to simulate a prey-chaser scenario. Finally, the agent control capabilities have been compared to those of a conventional autopilot. The good news is that an DRL agent performs reasonably well! In this work, the chosen high-performance airplane is the F-16.     What action space should you choose to train deep control policies for quadrotors? Check out our #ICRA2022 paper "A Benchmark Comparison of Learned Control Policies for Agile Quadrotor Flight"! We present the first benchmark comparison of existing learned control policies for agile quadrotor flight and show that training control policies that command body rates and collective thrust results in more robust sim-to-real transfer compared to training policies that directly specify individual rotor thrusts. Paper: https://lnkd.in/euxzDQ8U Narrated Video: https://lnkd.in/epkYcRTH Quadrotors are highly nonlinear dynamical systems that require carefully tuned controllers to be pushed to their physical limits. Recently, learning-based control policies have been proposed for quadrotors, as they would potentially allow learning direct mappings from high-dimensional raw sensory observations to actions. Due to sample inefficiency, training such learned controllers on the real platform is impractical or even impossible. Training in simulation is attractive but requires to transfer policies between domains, which demands trained policies to be robust to such domain gap. In this work, we make two contributions: (i) we perform the first benchmark comparison of existing learned control policies for agile quadrotor flight and show that training a control policy that commands body rates and thrust results in more robust sim-to-real transfer compared to a policy that directly specifies individual rotor thrusts, (ii) we demonstrate for the first time that such a control policy trained via deep reinforcement learning can control a quadrotor in real-world experiments at speeds over 45km/h. Kudos to Elia Kaufmann and Leonard Bauersfeld!     In the literature, behavioral car-following (CF) models and ACC algorithms are usually applied to mimic longitudinal dynamics of human-driven vehicles (HVs) and autonomous vehicles (AVs), respectively. However, from a modelling viewpoint, there is no reason to prefer CF models to simulate HVs, and ACC algorithms to simulate AVs. After all, when simulating a mixed traffic, we retain almost the same level of ignorance about the true dynamics of HVs and AVs. In this paper (https://lnkd.in/dpMuHUq5) we investigated what the ability of ACC algorithms from the literature is to capture the measured dynamics of commercial ACC-equipped vehicles, and whether the consolidated habit of applying linear control laws ‚Äì and not behavioral CF models ‚Äì to simulate AVs has significance in practice. Results are surprising!     Computing time-optimal trajectories for #quadcopters can now be done in just 10ms and onboard! This helps withstand both wind and dynamic environments! Check out our paper published in the IEEE Transactions on Robotics and its follow-up paper: PDF: https://lnkd.in/e8c9Azyq Video: https://lnkd.in/eF5SAZuV PDF: https://lnkd.in/eakmSvAk Video: https://lnkd.in/eBax5_Hs We tackle the problem of flying time-optimal trajectories through multiple waypoints with quadrotors. State-of-the-art solutions split the problem into a planning task (where a global, time-optimal trajectory is generated) and a control task (where this trajectory is accurately tracked). However, at the current state, generating a time-optimal trajectory that considers the full quadrotor model requires solving a difficult time allocation problem via optimization, which can take up to several hours. This is detrimental for replanning in presence of disturbances, such as wind or dynamic gates and obstacles. We overcome this issue by solving the time allocation problem and the control problem concurrently via Model Predictive Contouring Control (MPCC). Our #MPCC optimally selects the future states of the platform at runtime, while maximizing the progress along the reference path and minimizing the distance to it. We show that, even when tracking simplified trajectories, the proposed MPCC results in a path that approaches the true time-optimal one, and which can be generated in real-time. In a follow-up paper, we show how these trajectories can be replanned on the fly to adapt to changes in the environment. We showcase this adaptation capability by flying a quadrotor at more than 60 km/h on a racing track where gates are moving. Additionally, we show that our online replanning approach can cope with strong disturbances caused by winds of up to 68 km/h. References: "Model Predictive Contouring Control for Time-Optimal Quadrotor Flight", IEEE Transactions on Robotics, 2022.     People tend to think burnout is caused primarily by 1 thing. Being overworked. I actually think all these things contribute more to burnout: - lack of alignment (rowing in opposite directions) - lack of winning (losing causes burnout fast) - lack of proper incentives and recognition - lack of excitement about the vision (gotta be inspired) - lack of progress personally - lack of trust - lack of clear ownership and directive of what success looks like (more detailed than vision) - lack of enjoying working with the people on your team Lots of people love to work, but you'll get burnout from those things ^[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6922324732847476736?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6922324732847476736%29)

    My System Design preparation behind receiving a lot of offers. Freshworks was the first company I interviewed with for the System Design round ever, and I absolutely got wrecked in the round. I was not able to explain things about consistent hashing in a load balancer, trade-offs between why I chose NoSQL vs Relational DB, etc. Post 4 of 7 in my Interview Prep & Job Search. For others who have no idea what this is all about, I've linked the first post in the comments section. Check it if you feel like it. I started my HLD prep around December 2021 end, went to YouTube, and watched the famous Gaurav Sen playlist. Made notes after watching all the 37 videos from his playlist and used to revise them every morning and every night before sleep for a month. Attached the notes with the post (apologies for my terrible handwriting). Bought two books - "System Design Interview - An Insider's Guide" by Alex Xu, and "Designing data-intensive applications" by Martik Kleppmann as well. They're probably the best purchases I made in my career. I went through Alex Xu's book at least 15-20 times during my entire preparation journey. I also searched the entire youtube and made a personal playlist containing all the system design mock interviews existing on Youtube. There were around 50ish videos I found and I went through every single one of them. I'll leave the link to the playlist in the comments. Whenever I had an HLD interview, I used to revise the personal notes I made from Gaurav Sen videos and I also used to skim through the entire Alex Xu book as well. I got to a point where I was able to skim through the entire 300-page book in 20 mins. That's how many times I read and understood the book over and over again. After Freshworks, I never failed a single system design round. It became my strongest topic ever. Received the highest possible ratings in all my HLD rounds with all companies except with LinkedIn (made a terrible mistake with DB schema). I had a buddy, Nagasree kasa, we used to study HLD together and used to explain to each other the concepts we learned every alternative day. That tremendously helped in cementing what we learned. I asked my friend Sruthi Yagnavajjula to take an HLD mock interview. Being from a non-technical background, she gave me very positive feedback about my explanations and architecture and I also understood how I should approach and explain an HLD problem statement during the interviews. They both helped me realize that my system design skills were pretty good (Not bragging by any means). I had a habit of reading engineering blogs of many companies before, but I never focused that deeply. I used to do it as a hobby, but after I started HLD preparation, I must say I fell in love with System Design as a whole. I've attached my notes, Youtube playlist I made, links to both books in the post & comments section.     Still using cross-entropy loss or focal loss? Perhaps surprisingly, there is room for improvement here. Now you have a better choice: PolyLoss. Our just released ICLR‚Äô22 paper shows: with one line of code (see image), Polyloss improves all image classification, detection, and segmentation tasks, sometimes by a significant margin. Our Polyloss paper examines the Taylor expansion series of the losses and the effects of changing their coefficients. We find the leading term is the most important one, and simply adjusting it can result in significant gains on a diverse set of SOTA models. What is interesting is that different settings need different epsilon: positive, or negative.     Topic Modelling: Intentionally short primer and A mental model. After Philip Vollet‚Äôs post on Top2Vec, many of you pinged. So here you go. üëâ Criteria A: Discover topics in a corpus with long-form docs of size: small to medium & you are open to dealing with cleanup (stop words), muck with hyper-parameters & involve HITL to assign readable topics. - Use cases: Analyse employee emails (long-form) to understand the top N topics that lead to mass resignations. - 2 Options: Matrix factorisation (MF)-based & Probabilistic sampling-based. - Mode: Unsupervised A variant of MF: Decompose a term-doc frequency matrix A into W & H (in W, all rows (i) are docs & cols (j) are words, in H, all rows are words & cols are topics). Imagine Wij. Hjk. K is the number of topics & it is manually chosen. Idea is to reduce i.e ||A-W.H||. If SVD is used for MF then it‚Äôs LSA. The probabilistic variation of it is pLSA. Another variation of pLSA is NMF. But if you do this probabilistically using sampling tech like Gibbs sampling then it‚Äôs LDA. - Pros: The topics are open for good human interpretations. - Cons: By default word is the tactical unit, word order & context are ignored (Though you could play with the ngram range while generating a term-doc matrix, it‚Äôs still a BoW). You are also at the mercy of the implementation, I have ‚Äúheard‚Äù Mallet is ‚Äúdecent‚Äù. Finally, Can‚Äôt handle a huge corpus. üëâ Criteria B: Discover topics in a corpus of long or short texts & you don‚Äôt want to deal with corpus cleanup, a lot of hyper-parameters, leveraging SoTA LMs with some convenient features. - Use cases: Prev use-case + Analyse Trump tweets to understand the topics during the Capitol invasion - 2 Options: Top2vec & BERTopic - Mode: Top2vec (Unsupervised) & BERTopic (can do supervised, semi/guided & DTM). Both follow the same 5 steps, vectorize docs using algorithms (in the likes of Doc2Vec all the way up to Transformers), lower dimensions of docs using UMAP, make clusters using HDBSCAN, calculate centroids (which is the topic) & get Top N similar or closer docs to the centroids. But BERTopic varies in the last 2 steps (which is its weakness) & in the list of vectorization algorithms it supports. Ref the papers for more. - Pros: Both have some nice bells & whistles like search & Viz. The results show both works better with short texts with better coherence & diversity. SoTA vectorization algorithms take care of topic & doc semantics. - Cons: High-quality doc vectors come at a price & can be very slow. The main drawback of BERTTopic is that even though docs are vectorized using semantic vectors the topics are still vectorized using a variant of a BoW called c-TF-IDF. This is still a challenge. üëâ Criteria C: Your docs are represented by many *correlated* topics. Go for variational inference-based CTM - Correlated topic models. Fx BERTopic assumes "A doc pertains to one topic more than others" but it is far from reality in certain domains. #lsa #lda #top2vec[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6925757992227250176?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6925757992227250176%29)

    How did I manage tremendous amounts of companies and interviews? Post 2 of 7 in my Interview Prep & Job Search. For others who have no idea what this is all about, I've linked the first post in the comments section. Check it if you feel like it. So, how did I do it? Two Words - Notion & Google Calendar Every single day I used to follow up with multiple recruiters about updates on the interview process. I used to set REMINDERS, and TASKS on my Google Calendar every day so that I don't forget which company recruiter to contact for an update on which day! I've put all the companies applied, the rounds, the role, the team, and every single piece of information on a notion page (close to 70 companies, look at the image attached). This notion page also consisted of links to my resume, LinkedIn profile, leetcode profile for quick access, template messages to send to recruiters and employees for referrals, and also a couple of motivational quotes for me to see when I felt low. This Notion page was my single source of truth, it had links to job openings from company careers pages, emails, people whom I reached out to for referrals, and discussions I had with recruiters & hiring managers about the work, role, tech stack, team, interview structure, status in each round, and a lot more. But still, no matter how organized and planned I tried to be, things always fell out of place. I was ghosted by several companies. I kept trying to reach out to them for closure, either a yes or no. I mailed them, called them, and dropped them messages over LinkedIn for updates. Few of them were kind enough to give an answer, most of them were not. Btw, I've applied to many companies right from January itself, though I wanted to apply from February/March. The reason being, I know that the processes will take time so I started early.     We (Naresh and I) have been working on our Efficient Deep Learning book for a while with a top computer science book publisher. The book seeks to help the readers optimize their deep learning models, which we feel is a very relevant and timely topic. However, we realized that we were imposing constraints on the book because of the economic aspects of book publishing. For instance, why shouldn't the e-book be free for everyone to read? It shouldn't be under lock and key in a walled garden. Sure, we don't earn any royalties from those who just grab the PDF, but that's not what we are in it for. Another one: Why shouldn't the physical book have images in color, and syntax-highligted code? For publishers, it is way more profitable to print in black-and-white. However, we can self-publish in color and sell it at cost since we don't need to make a profit. Those who do want a physical book should actually be able to enjoy that experience. We are not in the book publishing business. I probably won't pick up such a big endeavor either in the future, but we want to do it right this one time. So starting now we are just going to put the PDFs and the codelabs / tutorials online for everyone to read and play with at: efficientdlbook.com. We have the first four chapters and the related codelabs available now, with more coming soon! We hope that by putting the book out there, we will get the feedback that we need to improve the book, and readers can access the content as it evolves. In the words of the Incredible Hulk, "I see this as an absolute win!". Please report errata / feedback at: https://lnkd.in/g7RXWCCx, and/or feel free to write to us at hello@efficientdlbook.com if you would like to collaborate / review / help in any capacity.[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6923712950696366080?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6923712950696366080%29)

    Highly recommended: "Interpretable Machine Learning: Fundamental Principles and 10 Grand Challenges" by Cynthia Rudin, Chaofan Chen, Zhi Chen, Haiyang Huang, Lesia Semenova, and Chudi Zhong Interpretability in machine learning (ML) is crucial for high-stakes decisions and troubleshooting. In this work, we provide fundamental principles for interpretable ML, and dispel common misunderstandings that dilute the importance of this crucial topic. We also identify 10 technical challenge areas in interpretable machine learning and provide history and background on each problem. Some of these problems are classically important, and some are recent problems that have arisen in the last few years. These problems are: (1) Optimizing sparse logical models such as decision trees; (2) Optimization of scoring systems; (3) Placing constraints into generalized additive models to encourage sparsity and better interpretability; (4) Modern case-based reasoning, including neural networks and matching for causal inference; (5) Complete supervised disentanglement of neural networks; (6) Complete or even partial unsupervised disentanglement of neural networks; (7) Dimensionality reduction for data visualization; (8) Machine learning models that can incorporate physics and other generative or causal constraints; (9) Characterization of the ‚ÄúRashomon set‚Äù of good models; and (10) Interpretable reinforcement learning. This survey is suitable as a starting point for statisticians and computer scientists interested in working in interpretable machine learning. #artificialintelligence #KI #machinelearning #DataScience #XAI #Interpretabilty #transparency #algorithms #explainableai #dataviz[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6919340488172924929?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6919340488172924929%29)

    A lot of ‚Äòinfluencers‚Äô recommend their list of 50+ books but don‚Äôt tell you how to choose the right books for YOU + how to read. Here‚Äôs the framework I use to solve for both those things: First identify your phase in life to choose the right books: üëâPhase #1) The ‚Äúsponge‚Äù phase: In this phase, you have time on your hands to explore different ideas/ topics. Read everything/ anything that you can get your hands on: there‚Äôs no need for book recommendations. The focus should be on consuming large volumes of material, and exponentially increasing your reading speed. üëâPhase #2) The synthesis phase: When you‚Äôre thinking about starting something new/ going on a new adventure, stir the pot in your brain: you‚Äôve fed it well in phase #1. Let your brain connect the dots from all the topics you‚Äôve learned about. The books you thought were most irrelevant usually end up being bridges- don‚Äôt underestimate any book. üëâPhase #3) The ‚Äúexecution‚Äù phase: There‚Äôs no time for leisurely reading at this stage- you‚Äôre already working on something. You‚Äôll crave bullet-sized bits of info to fill the holes in your knowledge to propel yourself to the next level. The information age is over, this is the curation phase. Find experts in your domain: they‚Äôve already read all the books/ made the mistakes you‚Äôre trying to avoid. You just need to suck out all the information from their brains- fast. Annoy them endlessly with questions over coffee, read everything they mention- fast, fill the gaps of info that you have, find another expert, rinse and repeat. If you try to jump between phases, you‚Äôre going to lose. You can‚Äôt skip steps. Here are 3 other common mistakes people make with reading books: üêíMistake #1) Not taking notes I go back and re-read my notes in the margins all the time. Helps tons. üêíMistake #2) Mental masturbation Reading without producing outcomes is like mental masturbation- it‚Äôs useless. If you want the whole experience(pun intended)- go out, test out what you learn in every book, rinse and repeat with every new one. üêíMistake #3) Relying heavily on book recommendations Big mistake. Different people are at different phases of their life, contextual relevance is underrated. Sometimes similar people get different amounts of value from the same book. You have your own path, fearlessly navigate it. The dots will connect for you in your own unique way. Hope this helps!     Something that does not get said enough- R is alive and well in production environments across the globe. Does this mean that I do not like Python? Absolutely not. I prefer Python for ETL and automation tasks. Does this mean that R cannot perform those tasks? No; however, it is personal preference. What type of business activities do I prefer R? 1. Dashboards- Shiny is an awesome application with great documentation (If you are new to my posts, I would not be in the data world without documentation). 2. Health Analytics- R has several packages that make analyzing healthcare data efficient, effective, and visually appealing. Additionally, data cleaning in R (Tidyverse, and the list goes on). 3. Structural Equation Modeling (SEM)- If I am doing research that involves SEM, I prefer R. UCLA's Advanced Research Computing for Statistical Methods and Data Analytics has detailed and awesome examples. I provide the R resources for each area listed above in the comments.     [Hyperparameter Tuning Knowledge Transfer from Small to Huge Network] Recently, Microsoft just published a paper on performing hyperparameter tuning on a small network that can be transferrable to a larger network, whether it is larger in width, depth, sequence length for the Transformers network, and even the training time! What does this mean? It means that we can perform hyperparameter tuning only on a smaller network, with of course much less computational cost, then transfer the best set of hyperparameters we get to the original huge network that we have, let's say the almighty GPT-3. In fact, the authors show that they outperformed published numbers of the 6.7B GPT-3 model, by performing hyperparameter tuning on a 40M GPT-3 down-sized model, with the tuning cost only 7% of the total pertaining cost! How is it possible? All of this can happen thanks to the technique of hyperparameters parameterization, called ¬µP (read: mu-P). Note that, this is not a hyperparameter tuning method, but it is a procedure to perform hyperparameter tuning on parameterized hyperparameters based on ¬µP. This is indeed a very interesting paper! It is worth sparing some of your time to read this paper, as attached in the comment section below :) BONUS: They have implemented this method and open-sourced it! You can see the link to the repo in the comment section below :) Please share your thoughts after reading the paper.     Pingouin is a library based on NumPy and pandas that offers a variety of statistical tests, including T-test, Pearson correlation, ANOVA, Chi-Square and many more. This library is a great alternative to SciPy, as it supports pandas dataframes and provides detailed results for each test. For example, the ttest_ind() function of SciPy returns only the T-value and p-value. In comparison, the ttest() function of Pingouin returns the T-value, p-value, degrees of freedom, effect size, 95% confidence interval, statistical power and the Bayes factor of the test. You can visit the link below for more information and let me know your thoughts in the comments!     I often write about how R programming is the fastest, easiest way for ANY professional to unlock advanced analytics. Seems like Microsoft agrees with me. üòÅ Many of my clients are starting to deploy Power BI to professionals that have traditionally used Microsoft Excel for their data work. These clients usually ask about empowering these professionals with analytics - especially predictive analytics. I advise to first get folks trained on Power BI fundamentals - especially construction and analysis of multidimensional histograms, bar charts, and line charts. In other words, get folks comfortable performing exploratory data analysis (EDA) with Power BI. Then I advise getting these folks training with R. Why? 1 - R programming is easy for Excel users to learn. 2 - Microsoft has heavily invested in R to extend Power BI. I usually get a healthy dose of skepticism regarding point 1. I don't blame folks for that and I don't expect them to take my word for it. If you give me 40 minutes I can prove to you that ANY professional with Excel skills can learn R. Watch my free webinar now: https://bit.ly/WhyRisEasy Unlock advanced analytics with R and Power BI.     From Yann LeCunn‚Ä¶ Video of a technical talk I gave: "A Path Towards Autonomous AI" Hosted by Baidu on 2022-02-22. TL;DR: - autonomous AI requires predictive world models - world models must be able to perform multimodal predictions - solution: Joint Embedding Predictive Architecture (JEPA) - JEPA makes prediction in representation space, and can choose to ignore irrelevant or hard-to-predict details. - JEPA can be trained non-contrastively by (1) making the representations of inputs maximally informative, (2) making the representations predictable from each other, (3) regularizing latent variables necessary for prediction. - JEPAs can be stacked to make long-term/long-range predictions in more abstract representation spaces. - Hierarchical JEPAs can be used for hierarchical planning. Backpropagation, or reverse-mode differentiation, is a special case within the general family of automatic differentiation algorithms that also includes the forward mode. Common sense is chronically hard to define and may differ from person to person, especially (but not exclusively) between subjects from different sub-populations. üîπ The authors propose their definition of common sense** and then operationalize it smartly. ** "ùò≥ùò¶ùò¢ùò¥ùò∞ùòØùò™ùòØùò® ùò¢ùò£ùò∞ùò∂ùòµ ùò±ùò≠ùò¢ùò∂ùò¥ùò™ùò£ùò≠ùò¶ ùò§ùò¢ùò∂ùò¥ùò¶ùò¥ ùò¢ùòØùò• ùò¶ùòßùòßùò¶ùò§ùòµùò¥ ùò∞ùòß ùò¥ùò¶ùòÆùò¢ùòØùòµùò™ùò§ ùòÆùò¶ùò¢ùòØùò™ùòØùò®ùò¥ ùò™ùòØ ùòØùò¢ùòµùò∂ùò≥ùò¢ùò≠ ùò≠ùò¢ùòØùò®ùò∂ùò¢ùò®ùò¶ùò¥ ùòµùò©ùò¢ùòµ ùò¢ùò≥ùò¶ ùò¢ùò§ùò§ùò¶ùò¥ùò¥ùò™ùò£ùò≠ùò¶ ùò£ùò∫ ùò¢ùò∑ùò¶ùò≥ùò¢ùò®ùò¶ ùò≥ùò¶ùò¢ùò¥ùò∞ùòØùò¢ùò£ùò≠ùò¶ ùò±ùò¶ùò≥ùò¥ùò∞ùòØùò¥" üîπ The authors leverage the fact that ùòÅùó≤ùó∫ùóΩùóºùóøùóÆùóπ ùó∂ùóªùó≥ùóºùóøùó∫ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª may provide us with some information about causality (precedence does not imply causation, but causation implies precedence). üîπ ùóßùó≤ùó∫ùóΩùóºùóøùóÆùóπ ùó∂ùóªùó≥ùóºùóøùó∫ùóÆùòÅùó∂ùóºùóª alone is susceptible to ùó∞ùóºùóªùó≥ùóºùòÇùóªùó±ùó∂ùóªùó¥ though. üîπ To mitigate potential confoundedness, the authors use ùòÅùó≤ùó∫ùóΩùóºùóøùóÆùóπ ùóΩùóøùóºùóΩùó≤ùóªùòÄùó∂ùòÅùòÜ ùó∫ùóÆùòÅùó∞ùóµùó∂ùóªùó¥. üîπ The framework (called ùó•ùó¢ùóñùóû) consists of four main components, implemented using various techniques, including an excellent open-source ùóöùó£ùóß-ùóù (https://6b.eleuther.ai/) as event sampler***, fine-tuned ROBERTa as a temporal predictor*** and ùó£ùóºùóπùòÜùóùùòÇùó∂ùó∞ùó≤***/**** (https://lnkd.in/d5yNhsPw) as intervention generator. üîπ ùó•ùó¢ùóñùóû outperforms certain benchmarks on COPA dataset, while underperforming others. At the same time it does not require task-specific finetuning and - as the authors conclude - "ùò™ùò¥ ùòÆùò∞ùò≥ùò¶ ùò™ùòØùòµùò¶ùò≥ùò±ùò≥ùò¶ùòµùò¢ùò£ùò≠ùò¶ ùò¢ùòØùò• ùò±ùò≥ùò∞ùò∑ùò™ùò•ùò¶ùò¥ ùò¢ ùò±ùò≥ùò∞ùòµùò∞ùòµùò∫ùò±ùò¶ ùòßùò∞ùò≥ ùò¢ùò•ùò∞ùò±ùòµùò™ùòØùò® ùò§ùò¢ùò∂ùò¥ùò¢ùò≠ ùò™ùòØùòßùò¶ùò≥ùò¶ùòØùò§ùò¶ ùòßùò≥ùò¢ùòÆùò¶ùò∏ùò∞ùò≥ùò¨ùò¥ ùòµùò∞ ùòØùò¢ùòµùò∂ùò≥ùò¢ùò≠ ùò≠ùò¢ùòØùò®ùò∂ùò¢ùò®ùò¶ ùòµùò¢ùò¥ùò¨ùò¥" üíé __________________________ *** Please refer to the paper for more details. **** PolyJuice is so exciting!     üéñ Hugging Face released #ViLT recently - the latest in VLP (Vision Language Pretraining ). The below diagram shows where the new ViLT model fits in the image hierarchy and what tasks you can do with it. üëâThere are V+L tasks that are a class-part like NLVR-Natural Language for Visual Reasoning and VQA-Visual Question Answering, Visual Navigation & VCR as they are much more complicated than higher-order tasks like (OCR or Image Captioning) which I call derived or advanced tasks (for lack of a better word) üëâFor instance, we could combine Image and Language encoders trained in isolation and add cross-attention to create a generative model to tackle OCR or Image Captioning (That‚Äôs exactly what VisionEncoderDecoder class does). üëâBut we cannot tackle derived tasks the same way, we need to train image and language data together with image level loss + language level loss + alignment loss. That‚Äôs exactly what VLP does for you and ViLT is the latest and greatest in VLP. It has several advantages over its predecessors like UNiTER, VisualBERT and LXMERT etc but they are cumbersome. Read the primers linked below for more details. (The difference between higher-order and derived tasks is even though higher-order tasks are multimodal they don‚Äôt necessarily need a VLP model to tackle them) - If you are new to VLP => https://lnkd.in/gaDQEJwd - If you are confusing ü§ó VisionEncDec, VLP and CLIP => https://lnkd.in/gmYsEwHh - If you need help on contrastive learning basics to understand CLIP better => https://lnkd.in/dRvhBuJk - ViLT docs => https://lnkd.in/g4Fd_WhA - Niels, the contributor of this model has made a post with links to examples, check it out.     Hey folks, ‚úî‚ö° üåà üèÜü•á ùêÄ ùêíùêîùêëùêïùêÑùêò ùêéùêÖ ùêçùêÑùêîùêëùêÄùêã ùêÄùêìùêìùêÑùêçùêìùêàùêéùêç ùêåùêéùêÉùêÑùêãùêí ùêàùêç ùêÉùêÑùêÑùêè ùêãùêÑùêÄùêëùêçùêàùêçùêÜ ü•áüèÜüåà‚ö°‚úî by Alana de Santana Correi and Esther Luna Colombini ‚ö°‚ö° Abstract ‚ö°‚ö°: ‚úÖ In humans, Attention is a core property of all perceptual and cognitive operations. Given our limited ability to process competing sources, attention mechanisms select, modulate, and focus on the information most relevant to behavior. ‚úÖ For decades, concepts and functions of attention have been studied in philosophy, psychology, neuroscience, and computing. For the last six years, this property has been widely explored in deep neural networks. Currently, the state-of-the-art in Deep Learning is represented by neural attention models in several application domains. ‚úÖ This survey provides a comprehensive overview and analysis of developments in neural attention models. We systematically reviewed hundreds of architectures in the area, identifying and discussing those in which attention has shown a significant impact. We also developed and made public an automated methodology to facilitate the development of reviews in the area. ‚úÖ By critically analyzing 650 works, we describe the primary uses of attention in convolutional, recurrent networks and generative models, identifying common subgroups of uses and applications. Furthermore, we describe the impact of attention in different application domains and their impact on neural networks‚Äô interpretability. ‚úÖ Finally, we list possible trends and opportunities for further research, hoping that this review will provide a succinct overview of the main attentional models in the area and guide researchers in developing future approaches that will drive further improvements.
