It builds the model in a stage-wise fashion like other boosting methods do, and it generalizes them by allowing optimization of an arbitrary differentiable loss function. The idea of gradient boosting originated in the observation by Leo Breiman that boosting can be interpreted as an optimization algorithm on a suitable cost function. XGBoost(eXtreme Gradient Boosting) is an open-source software library which provides the state-of-the-art gradient boosting framework packaged in many languages, such as C++, Python and Java. It aims to provide a ‚ÄùScalable, Portable and Distributed Gradient Boosting Library‚Äù. It runs on a single machine, as well as the distributed processing frameworks Apache Hadoop, Apache Spark, and Apache Flink. The scope of this manuscript is to set a background for the gradient boosting algorithms, explain the theoretical subset of the XGBoost framework that has been implemented as a part of the JADBIO framework and compare JADBIO‚Äôs implementation to the original. The JADBIO version of gradient boosting, implements a convenient subset of the functionality of the XGBoost framework, and has also been extended to account for the case of survival optimization as well.     Want to upgrade your SQL skills for an interview or for your job? Here's how I'd break down your time: Common topics (should master these): 1. SELECT and WHERE for filtering and selection 2. COUNT, SUM, MAX, GROUP BY, HAVING for aggregating data" 3. DISTINCT, COUNT DISTINCT for producing useful distinct lists and distinct aggregates 4. OUTER (e.g. LEFT) and INNER JOIN when/where to use them 5. Strings and time conversions 6. UNION and UNION ALL. Topics that come up regularly (be familiar with them): 1. DML/DDL/DCL concepts 2. Handling NULLs creatively (e.g. with COALESCE) 3. Subqueries and the impact of subqueries on efficiency of the query 4. Temporary tables 5. Self joins 6. Window functions like PARTITION, LEAD, LAG, NTILE 7. UDFs (user defined functions) 8. Use of indexes in querying to make operations faster. Important, but more rare topics (useful to know): 1. Recursive CTEs 2. Dynamic SQL generation 3. Query optimization 4. Materialized views What would you add, or change? #datascience #data #sql[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6888114680242458624?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6888114680242458624%29)

    Hey folks, üî• üî• ùêñùê°ùêûùêß ùêèùêëùêÑùêÇùêàùêíùêàùêéùêç, ùêëùêÑùêÇùêÄùêãùêã ùêöùêßùêù ùêÖùêíùêÇùêéùêëùêÑ ùê¢ùê¨ ùêçùêéùêì ùêÑùêçùêéùêîùêÜùêá üî• üî• Performance metrics like PRECISION, RECALL, and FSCORE are commonly used for classification models A PRECISION is the percentage of correctly identified POSITIVEs: PRECISION = True Positives/(True Positives + False Positives) = TP/(TP+FP) RECALL refers to the number of actual POSITIVES that have been correctly identified: RECALL = TP/(TP + False Negatives(FN)) FScore (and its weighted variant F_beta score) combines PRECISION and RECALL and equal to their harmonic mean: FSCORE = 2* PRECISION*RECALL/(PRECISION + RECALL) Well, the precision-recall curve (or FScore) seems to be a powerful metric for measuring model performance There is a catch, though! It is noteworthy that TRUE NEGATIVES do not appear in the F-SCORE definition. As a result, the model performance of the NEGATIVE CLASS is TOTALLY IGNORED It can be acceptable in many scenarios, including anomaly detection In case you care about NEGATIVE CLASS performance, use the following metrics: - Balanced Accuracy - Matthew's Correlation Coefficient - Cohen's Kappa(close to F1 for high TN) which are taking NEGATIVE CLASS performance into account For more info see links in the COMMENTS ENJOY, LEARN & KEEP IMPROVING! üçì üçí ùï±ùñîùñëùñëùñîùñú Michael(Mike) Erlihson, PhD for awesome DS/ML/math resources üçì üçí #modelperformance #machinelearning #datascience #accuracy #metrics[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6876058056111730689?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6876058056111730689%29)

    Need a dataset for multi-agent (cooperative) perception in driving applications? I'm happy to announce the Cooperative Driving Dataset (CODD)! This dataset includes lidar data from multiple vehicles navigating simultaneously through a diverse set of driving scenarios and was created to enable further research in cooperative 3D object detection, multi-agent SLAM and point cloud registration. The dataset was generated using CARLA and provides 108 sequences (125 frames each) across all 10 available maps, ranging from small rural areas to dense urban zones. The sequences have, on average, 10 vehicles, all of which provide synchronised point clouds. The ground-truth 3D bounding box annotations are also provided for all vehicles and pedestrians, along with the absolute pose of each lidar sensor at each timestep. We also provide the source-code used to generate the dataset, allowing users to customise the simulation settings and sensor configurations to create their own version of the dataset. For more details, please see the links below. PYTHON contains a bunch of NLP packages and tools which you can use to develop you NLP models.     Hey folks, The DATA SCIENCE DESIGN MANUAL - FREE BOOK by Steven S. Skiena "This engaging and clearly written textbook/reference provides a must-have introduction to the rapidly emerging interdisciplinary field of data science. It focuses on the principles fundamental to becoming a good data scientist and the key skills needed to build systems for collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data. The Data Science Design Manual is a source of practical insights that highlights what really matters in analyzing data, and provides an intuitive understanding of how these core concepts can be used. The book does not emphasize any particular programming language or suite of data-analysis tools, focusing instead on high-level discussion of important design principles. This easy-to-read text ideally serves the needs of undergraduate and early graduate students embarking on an "Introduction to Data Science" course. It reveals how this discipline sits at the intersection of statistics, computer science, and machine learning, with a distinct heft and character of its own. Practitioners in these and related fields will find this book perfect for self-study as well." LINK for BOOK DOWNLOAD: https://lnkd.in/ddeVCkMN ENJOY, LEARN and KEEP IMPROVING!!     Hey folks, GRAND MACHINE LEARNING CHEAT SHEET: One of the best " ... This cheat sheet is a condensed version of MACHINE LEARNING manual, which contains many classical equations and diagrams on machine learning, and aims to help you quickly recall knowledge and ideas in machine learning. It has two significant advantages: 1. Clearer symbols. Mathematical formulas use quite a lot of confusing symbols. For example, X can be a set, a random variable, or a matrix. This is very confusing and makes it very difficult for readers to understand the meaning of math formulas. This cheat sheet tries to standardize the usage of symbols, and all symbols are clearly pre-defined, see section 2. Less thinking jumps. In many machine learning books, authors omit some intermediary steps of a mathematical proof process, which may save some space but causes difficulty for readers to understand this formula and readers get lost in the middle way of the derivation process. This cheat sheet tries to keep important intermediary steps as where as possible..." ENJOY, LEARN and KEEP IMPROVING!     Natural language processing (NLP) This is the 30th day of 40 days of AI and we are covering the Next Big Breakthrough in AI according to Harvard Business Review. In recent years, Natural Language Processing (NLP) models have achieved phenomenal success in linguistic and semantic tasks like text classification, machine translation, cognitive dialogue systems, information retrieval via Natural Language Understanding (NLU), and Natural Language Generation (NLG). This feat is primarily attributed due to the seminal Transformer architecture, leading to designs such as BERT, GPT (I, II, III), etc. Although these large-size models have achieved unprecedented performances, they come at high computational costs. Consequently, some of the recent NLP architectures have utilized concepts of transfer learning, pruning, quantization, and knowledge distillation to achieve moderate model sizes while keeping nearly similar performances as achieved by their predecessors.     Hey folks, FREQUENTIST vs BAYESIAN STATISTICS: THE SIMPLEST EXPLANATION + BONUS(UNRELATED) : HOW TO BUILD CAREER IN DATA SCIENCE BOOK Frequentist and Bayesian are types of INFERENTIAL STATISTICS TECHNIQUES. INFERENTIAL STATISTICS: Draw a conclusion about ENTIRE GROUP based ONLY on a SAMPLE FROM this group. COIN-SIMPLE EXPLANATION: Imagine that you‚Äôve thrown a COIN, but you can‚Äôt see which side it fell on. FREQUENTIST: I don‚Äôt know anything about the probability of HEAD/ TAIL. GIVEN the coin heads up, the HEAD PROBABILITY is 1and TAIL PROBABILITY is 0; GIVEN the coin lands TAIL UP, TAIL PROBABILITY is 1 and HEAD PROBABILITY is 0. BAYESIAN: TAIL and HEAD PROBABILITies have CLOSE VALUES (about 1/2) What is the DIFFERENCE? FREQUENTIST: We know nothing about QUANTITY of INTEREST(parameter), before we do some experiments, from which we can estimate this parameter. But if we throw a coin 10000 times and get 5098 heads, then HEAD PROBABILITY is close to 0.5. FREQUENTIST: Probabilities are fundamentally related to EVENT FREQUENCIES BAYESIAN: We know SOMETHING about a parameter before carrying out a single experiment on it. What do we know? PROBABILITY DISTRIBUTION of this parameter!! Experiments just HELP to make this DISTRIBUTION more ‚Äúclose to reality‚Äù BAYESIAN: Probabilities are fundamentally based our own KNOWLEDGE about an event FREQUENTIST: Parameter to be estimated is DETERMINISTIC, has some DETERMINISTIC value, we want to estimate. The parameter estimation UNCERTAINTY can be assessed, for example, based on the assumptions of the sample/population distribution. BAYESIAN: Parameter, we are estimating, is RANDOM, No ONE RIGHT ANSWER for the parameter, has an UNCERTAINTY BUILD-IN ENJOY, LEARN and KEEP IMPROVING!!     Proud to share our 150-page "proto-book" with Michael Bronstein, Joan Bruna and Taco Cohen on geometric deep learning! https://lnkd.in/d9SCkMv Through the lens of symmetries, invariances and group theory, we attempt to distill "all you need to build the neural architectures that are all you need". All the 'usual suspects' such as CNNs, GNNs, Transformers and LSTMs are covered, while also including recent exciting developments such as Spherical CNNs, SO(3)-Transformers and Gauge Equivariant Mesh CNNs. Hence we believe that our work can be a useful way to navigate the increasingly challenging landscape of deep learning architectures. arXiv (and other goodies, blogs and talks) coming soon!     The most "devil-is-in-the-details" #MachineLearning subfield is Computer Vision. Let me demonstrate this with the simplest example I could come up with: Resizing an Image Here. I simply resize an image with most popular Python CV libraries: PIL, PyTorch, TensorFlow, OpenCV NONE of them gives the same result (play with my Colab notebook yourself ‚¨áÔ∏è)! And No, small differences matter a lot actually (Parmar et al., 2021). - Do not assume anything. - Always visualize the data at every step. Utilize your biological vision but do not count on it. - Implement tests. Tests of what you expect at every step. - Be cautious when migrating from one framework to another (e.g. TensorFlow to PyTorch). - Study good old signal processing (Fourier Transform, anti-aliasing, wavelets etc.). - Remember that saying "I know this" is a dangerous thing.     #Robots are networks of networks exchanging information in a time-sensitive manner. #FPGAs have unmatched #realtime capabilities and arguably, are the best compute substrate for #roboticists and robotic applications. Zishen, Bo, Thomas, Jie, Yuhao, Yu, Arijit and Shaoshan write about this and believe that #FPGAs are the best compute substrate for robotic applications for several reasons: #First, robotic algorithms are still evolving rapidly, and thus any ASIC-based accelerators will be months or even years behind the state-of-the-art algorithms; on the other hand, FPGAs can be dynamically updated as needed. #Second, robotic workloads are highly diverse, thus it is difficult for any ASIC-based robotic computing accelerator to reach economies of scale in the near future; on the other hand, FPGAs are a cost-effective and energy-effective alternative before one type ofaccelerator reaches economies of scale. #Third, compared to SoCs that have reached economies of scale, e.g., mobile SoCs, FPGAs deliver a significant performance advantage. #Fourth, partial reconfiguration allows multiple robotic workloads to time-share an FPGA, thus allowing one chip to serve multiple applications, leading to overall cost and energy reduction.     Check out our #CVPR2021 work on making NMS mathematically differentiable. GrooMeD-NMS: Grouped Mathematically Differentiable NMS for Monocular 3D Object Detection Joint work with Garrick Brazil and Xiaoming Liu (MSU) Project: https://lnkd.in/eSkAra8 Paper: https://lnkd.in/eUWxncU Code and Models: https://lnkd.in/eXMrfWK Demo: https://lnkd.in/ezk2jp3 Modern 3D object detectors have immensely benefited from the end-to-end learning idea. However, most of them use a post-processing algorithm called Non-Maximal Suppression (NMS) only during inference. In this paper, we present and integrate GrooMeD-NMS -- a novel Grouped Mathematically Differentiable NMS for monocular 3D object detection, such that the network is trained end-to-end with a loss on the boxes after NMS. We first formulate NMS as a matrix operation and then group and mask the boxes in an unsupervised manner to obtain a simple closed-form expression of the NMS. GrooMeD-NMS addresses the mismatch between training and inference pipelines and, therefore, forces the network to select the best 3D box in a differentiable manner. As a result, GrooMeD-NMS achieves state-of-the-art monocular 3D object detection results on the KITTI dataset.[‚Ä¶see more](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:6786321683381841920?updateEntityUrn=urn%3Ali%3Afs_feedUpdate%3A%28V2%2Curn%3Ali%3Aactivity%3A6786321683381841920%29)

    Recently, I spent some time on reading books/papers about visual SLAM. The difficult part for me is about Lie theory (very important in modern estimation algorithms for robotics). The visual SLAM book I recommended before only gives some intuitive explanations and lists some important results. To get better understanding of this theory, I tried to look for better materials on this topic. Unfortunately, most of the literature on Lie theory is too abstract to learn. Finally, I got this short, dense, and engineer-friendly paper (full of equations): "A micro Lie theory for state estimation in robotics " https://lnkd.in/eRBFMBc. The authors implement a C++11 Lie theory library, called manif, based on the paper: https://lnkd.in/eJD_Q-F. They also create a cheat sheet here: https://lnkd.in/eZFKxy9.
